cards.title: Stars on the street / Ken Hermann's Hollywood street lookalikes

item.title: Ken Hermann's Hollywood street lookalikes
item.trailText: Danish photographer Ken Hermann has taken a series of pictures of Los Angeles street performers, many of them dressed as famous Hollywood characters
item.standFirst:
While on an assignment in Los Angeles in March, Danish photographer Ken Hermann became interested in the street performers he’d spot near his hotel on Hollywood Boulevard. Many of them were dressed as famous Hollywood characters, and he saw the opportunity for a more personal project. “What interested me was seeing whether you could show the person behind the mask,” he says. “One performer backed out because he thought taking a picture without his mask on was unprofessional and insulting to the character.” Hermann hopes the photos come across as “a little surreal, a little weird. Instead of just picking the best-dressed ones, which almost looked like the real deal, I wanted characters with a little bit of oddness.”

  • See more of his work at kenhermann.com

displayImages.caption:
Minnie Mouse - Milagro Aguiar

“This was one of the first shots: I wanted one of the classic characters,” says Hermann. “I like the contrast between her age and the very childish, girly dress.”
displayImages.altText: Ken Hermann Hollywood Street Characters Street Performers
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Minnie Mouse - Milagro Aguiar

“This was one of the first shots: I wanted one of the classic characters,” says Hermann. “I like the contrast between her age and the very childish, girly dress.”

displayImages.caption:
Captain Boulevard – Jason Hughes

“This is a made-up superhero. Many of the performers want to get into the acting industry – they hope they’ll get spotted on the street, playing a character.”
displayImages.altText: Ken Hermann Hollywood Street Characters Street Performers
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Captain Boulevard – Jason Hughes

“This is a made-up superhero. Many of the performers want to get into the acting industry – they hope they’ll get spotted on the street, playing a character.”

displayImages.caption:
Darth Vader – Joe

“This guy is a full-time actor and does this to get some cash. He wasn’t keen on doing the photo without his mask on: he didn’t want to share too much of his privacy.”
displayImages.altText: Ken Hermann Hollywood Street Characters Street Performers
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Darth Vader – Joe

“This guy is a full-time actor and does this to get some cash. He wasn’t keen on doing the photo without his mask on: he didn’t want to share too much of his privacy.”

displayImages.caption:
Popeye – Ramses Zavola

“I chose this setting because of the combination of studio flash and sunlight – it’s a little bit unreal, there’s so much light on him.”
displayImages.altText: Ken Hermann Hollywood Street Characters Street Performers
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Popeye – Ramses Zavola

“I chose this setting because of the combination of studio flash and sunlight – it’s a little bit unreal, there’s so much light on him.”

displayImages.caption:
Superman – Javier Francisco

“This guy had quite a lot of problems in the beginning – there’s another Superman on the Boulevard so there’s been a turf war. The other Superman thought he was better.”
displayImages.altText: Ken Hermann Hollywood Street Characters Street Performers
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Superman – Javier Francisco

“This guy had quite a lot of problems in the beginning – there’s another Superman on the Boulevard so there’s been a turf war. The other Superman thought he was better.”

displayImages.caption:
Chewbacca – Jabari Farrow

“We wanted to shoot Chewbacca standing between some trees in a park but it didn’t work out, so we almost gave up. But then as we were driving back I spotted this overpass and it was perfect.”
displayImages.altText: Ken Hermann Hollywood Street Characters Street Performers
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Chewbacca – Jabari Farrow

“We wanted to shoot Chewbacca standing between some trees in a park but it didn’t work out, so we almost gave up. But then as we were driving back I spotted this overpass and it was perfect.”

displayImages.caption:
Bumblebee – Victor Borboa

“Victor is a full-time electrician and just does this for fun. It all started with him and his son making these kinds of costumes for a school competition, and he just got really into it.”
displayImages.altText: Ken Hermann Hollywood Street Characters Street Performers
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Bumblebee – Victor Borboa

“Victor is a full-time electrician and just does this for fun. It all started with him and his son making these kinds of costumes for a school competition, and he just got really into it.”

displayImages.caption:
Marilyn Monroe – April Q Russell

“Her name is ‘Black Marilyn of Hollywood Boulevard’. She only does this part-time: she’s a full-time producer and I think she does this to make some extra cash.”
displayImages.altText: Ken Hermann Hollywood Street Characters Street Performers
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Marilyn Monroe – April Q Russell

“Her name is ‘Black Marilyn of Hollywood Boulevard’. She only does this part-time: she’s a full-time producer and I think she does this to make some extra cash.”

displayImages.caption:
Zorro – Jordi lluch

“We took this picture on an overpass on the outskirts of LA. There’s this shadow going through the whole image that’s kind of slicing him in half.”
displayImages.altText: Ken Hermann Hollywood Street Characters Street Performers
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Zorro – Jordi lluch

“We took this picture on an overpass on the outskirts of LA. There’s this shadow going through the whole image that’s kind of slicing him in half.”

displayImages.caption:
Mad Hatter – Jason

“He was already acting in Australia, and moved to LA to continue his career. He now has a full-time job as an impersonator, where he plays different characters – like the Mad Hatter.”
displayImages.altText: Ken Hermann Hollywood Street Characters Street Performers
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Mad Hatter – Jason

“He was already acting in Australia, and moved to LA to continue his career. He now has a full-time job as an impersonator, where he plays different characters – like the Mad Hatter.”

displayImages.caption:
Thor – Vasyl litvynchuk

“Next to our hotel there was this dumpster with a sofa and a couch. I thought it would be nice to stand him on top of something, but without him looking too masculine. He’s also holding his cape in quite a sensitive way.”
displayImages.altText: Ken Hermann Hollywood Street Characters Street Performers
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Thor – Vasyl litvynchuk

“Next to our hotel there was this dumpster with a sofa and a couch. I thought it would be nice to stand him on top of something, but without him looking too masculine. He’s also holding his cape in quite a sensitive way.”

displayImages.caption:
Spiderman – Rashade Rouse

“This performer was really into it. He was working out every morning to have the right body.”
displayImages.altText: Ken Hermann Hollywood Street Characters Street Performers
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Spiderman – Rashade Rouse

“This performer was really into it. He was working out every morning to have the right body.”

displayImages.caption:
Charlie Chaplin – Tobias Santiago

“Tobias is a grand old man – he was one of the first characters on the Boulevard. He has his own corner. He’s been acting there for 15 years and is well respected by the others.”
displayImages.altText: Ken Hermann Hollywood Street Characters Street Performers
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Charlie Chaplin – Tobias Santiago

“Tobias is a grand old man – he was one of the first characters on the Boulevard. He has his own corner. He’s been acting there for 15 years and is well respected by the others.”

Minnie Mouse - Milagro Aguiar

“This was one of the first shots: I wanted one of the classic characters,” says Hermann. “I like the contrast between her age and the very childish, girly dress.”
image.altText: Ken Hermann Hollywood Street Characters Street Performers
image.cleanCaption:

cards.title: Shadowlands / Readers' photos on the theme of shade
cards.rawTitle: Readers' photos on the theme of shade

item.title: Shadowlands: readers' photos on the theme of shade
item.trailText: For last week’s photography assignment in the Observer New Review we asked you to share your photos on the theme of shade via GuardianWitness. Here’s a selection of our favourites
item.standFirst:
For last week’s photography assignment in the Observer New Review we asked you to share your photos on the theme of shade via GuardianWitness. Here’s a selection of our favourites

  • Share your photos on this week’s theme ‘blush’

cards.title: Memory Lane / Royal Ascot down the years

item.title: Memory Lane: Royal Ascot down the years
item.trailText: We have had a rummage through the archives to take a look at the racegoers, and a bit of racing, from yesteryear
item.standFirst: We have had a rummage through the archives to take a look at the racegoers, and a bit of racing, from yesteryear

displayImages.caption: Circa 1865 A crowd of racegoers on the grandstand at Ascot. Photograph: Hulton Archive/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Circa 1865 A crowd of racegoers on the grandstand at Ascot
displayImages.cleanCaption: Circa 1865 A crowd of racegoers on the grandstand at Ascot.

displayImages.caption: 1912 The Prince of Wales’s Stakes at Ascot. Photograph: Topical Press Agency/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: 1912 The Prince of Wales’s Stakes at Ascot.
displayImages.cleanCaption: 1912 The Prince of Wales’s Stakes at Ascot.

displayImages.caption: 1921 Racegoers tuck into a picnic by the side of their car. Photograph: Topical Press Agency/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: 1921 Racegoers tuck into a picnic by the side of their car
displayImages.cleanCaption: 1921 Racegoers tuck into a picnic by the side of their car.

displayImages.caption: 1922: Major and Mrs Hedges stride purposefully about in their finery. Photograph: Topical Press Agency/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: 1922:  Major and Mrs Hedges stride purposefully about in their finery
displayImages.cleanCaption: 1922: Major and Mrs Hedges stride purposefully about in their finery.

displayImages.caption: 1924 A horse racing official testing the scales in the jockey’s weighing room in preparation for Royal Ascot. Photograph: Topical Press Agency/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: 1924 A horse racing official testing the scales in the jockey’s weighing room in preparation for Royal Ascot.
displayImages.cleanCaption: 1924 A horse racing official testing the scales in the jockey’s weighing room in preparation for Royal Ascot.

displayImages.caption: 1928 Brown Jack, ridden by Steve Donoghue, wins the Ascot Stakes. The following year at Royal Ascot Brown Jack triumphed in the first of his six consecutive Queen Alexandra Stakes, the longest race in the Flat racing calendar. His sequence of victories made him one of the most popular racehorses in the history of British racing, and he is described in the meeting’s official guide as “arguably Royal Ascot’s greatest equine legend”. A bronze statue of Brown Jack, by the equestrian painter Sir Alfred Munnings, can be found at Ascot. Photograph: ANL/Rex Shutterstock
displayImages.altText: 1928 Brown Jack, ridden by Steve Donoghue, wins the Ascot Stakes. The following year at Royal Ascot Brown Jack triumphed in the first of his six consecutive Queen Alexandra Stakes, the longest race in the Flat racing calendar. His sequence of victories made him one of the most popular racehorses in the history of British racing, and he is described in the meeting’s official guide as “arguably Royal Ascot’s greatest equine legend”. A bronze statue of Brown Jack, by the equestrian painter Sir Alfred Munnings, can be found at Ascot.
displayImages.cleanCaption: 1928 Brown Jack, ridden by Steve Donoghue, wins the Ascot Stakes. The following year at Royal Ascot Brown Jack triumphed in the first of his six consecutive Queen Alexandra Stakes, the longest race in the Flat racing calendar. His sequence of victories made him one of the most popular racehorses in the history of British racing, and he is described in the meeting’s official guide as “arguably Royal Ascot’s greatest equine legend”. A bronze statue of Brown Jack, by the equestrian painter Sir Alfred Munnings, can be found at Ascot.

displayImages.caption: 1930 Racegoers walk through a field on their way from the railway station to the Royal Enclosure at Ascot. Photograph: Topical Press Agency/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: 1930 Racegoers walk through a field on their way from the railway station to the Royal Enclosure at Ascot
displayImages.cleanCaption: 1930 Racegoers walk through a field on their way from the railway station to the Royal Enclosure at Ascot.

displayImages.caption: 1931 Racegoers mingle around the paddock in front of the newly constructed Totalisator. The building cost over £100,000 to erect. The smaller buildings next to the Tote board were also erected and there were 360 pigeon holes for racegoers to place their bets. Photograph: J. A. Hampton/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: 1931 Racegoers mingle around the paddock in front of the newly constructed Totalisator. The building cost over £100,000 to erect. The smaller buildings next to the Tote board were also erected and there were 360 pigeon holes for racegoers to place their bets.
displayImages.cleanCaption: 1931 Racegoers mingle around the paddock in front of the newly constructed Totalisator. The building cost over £100,000 to erect. The smaller buildings next to the Tote board were also erected and there were 360 pigeon holes for racegoers to place their bets.

displayImages.caption: 1933 Two women dressed up for the second day at Royal Ascot. Photograph: Topical Press Agency/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: 1933 Two women dressed up for the second day at Royal Ascot
displayImages.cleanCaption: 1933 Two women dressed up for the second day at Royal Ascot.

displayImages.caption: 1935 Fashionable racegoers stop to listen to an accordion player and admire his pet monkey on the first day of Royal Ascot. Photograph: Topical Press Agency/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: 1935 Fashionable racegoers stop to listen to an accordion player and admire his pet monkey on the first day of Royal Ascot
displayImages.cleanCaption: 1935 Fashionable racegoers stop to listen to an accordion player and admire his pet monkey on the first day of Royal Ascot.

image.cleanCaption: 1912 The Prince of Wales’s Stakes at Ascot.

image.caption: 1921 Racegoers tuck into a picnic by the side of their car. Photograph: Topical Press Agency/Getty Images

image.cleanCaption: 1921 Racegoers tuck into a picnic by the side of their car.

image.caption: 1922: Major and Mrs Hedges stride purposefully about in their finery. Photograph: Topical Press Agency/Getty Images
image.altText: 1922:  Major and Mrs Hedges stride purposefully about in their finery
image.cleanCaption: 1922: Major and Mrs Hedges stride purposefully about in their finery.

image.caption: 1924 A horse racing official testing the scales in the jockey’s weighing room in preparation for Royal Ascot. Photograph: Topical Press Agency/Getty Images
image.altText: 1924 A horse racing official testing the scales in the jockey’s weighing room in preparation for Royal Ascot.
image.cleanCaption: 1924 A horse racing official testing the scales in the jockey’s weighing room in preparation for Royal Ascot.

image.caption: 1928 Brown Jack, ridden by Steve Donoghue, wins the Ascot Stakes. The following year at Royal Ascot Brown Jack triumphed in the first of his six consecutive Queen Alexandra Stakes, the longest race in the Flat racing calendar. His sequence of victories made him one of the most popular racehorses in the history of British racing, and he is described in the meeting’s official guide as “arguably Royal Ascot’s greatest equine legend”. A bronze statue of Brown Jack, by the equestrian painter Sir Alfred Munnings, can be found at Ascot. Photograph: ANL/Rex Shutterstock
image.altText: 1928 Brown Jack, ridden by Steve Donoghue, wins the Ascot Stakes. The following year at Royal Ascot Brown Jack triumphed in the first of his six consecutive Queen Alexandra Stakes, the longest race in the Flat racing calendar. His sequence of victories made him one of the most popular racehorses in the history of British racing, and he is described in the meeting’s official guide as “arguably Royal Ascot’s greatest equine legend”. A bronze statue of Brown Jack, by the equestrian painter Sir Alfred Munnings, can be found at Ascot.
image.cleanCaption: 1928 Brown Jack, ridden by Steve Donoghue, wins the Ascot Stakes. The following year at Royal Ascot Brown Jack triumphed in the first of his six consecutive Queen Alexandra Stakes, the longest race in the Flat racing calendar. His sequence of victories made him one of the most popular racehorses in the history of British racing, and he is described in the meeting’s official guide as “arguably Royal Ascot’s greatest equine legend”. A bronze statue of Brown Jack, by the equestrian painter Sir Alfred Munnings, can be found at Ascot.

image.caption: 1930 Racegoers walk through a field on their way from the railway station to the Royal Enclosure at Ascot. Photograph: Topical Press Agency/Getty Images
image.altText: 1930 Racegoers walk through a field on their way from the railway station to the Royal Enclosure at Ascot
image.cleanCaption: 1930 Racegoers walk through a field on their way from the railway station to the Royal Enclosure at Ascot.

image.caption: 1931 Racegoers mingle around the paddock in front of the newly constructed Totalisator. The building cost over £100,000 to erect. The smaller buildings next to the Tote board were also erected and there were 360 pigeon holes for racegoers to place their bets. Photograph: J. A. Hampton/Getty Images
image.altText: 1931 Racegoers mingle around the paddock in front of the newly constructed Totalisator. The building cost over £100,000 to erect. The smaller buildings next to the Tote board were also erected and there were 360 pigeon holes for racegoers to place their bets.
image.cleanCaption: 1931 Racegoers mingle around the paddock in front of the newly constructed Totalisator. The building cost over £100,000 to erect. The smaller buildings next to the Tote board were also erected and there were 360 pigeon holes for racegoers to place their bets.

cards.title: Grand designs / Yves Saint Laurent at the Bowes Museum
cards.rawTitle: Yves Saint Laurent at the Bowes Museum

item.title: Yves Saint Laurent at the Bowes Museum
item.trailText: The Bowes Museum, situated in Barnard Castle, County Durham, has scooped more well known London institutions in hosting Yves Saint Laurent: Style is Eternal, the first exhibition in the UK to present a comprehensive display of the French designer’s work and life.
item.standFirst:
The Bowes Museum, situated in Barnard Castle, County Durham, has scooped more well known London institutions in hosting Yves Saint Laurent: Style is Eternal, the first exhibition in the UK to present a comprehensive display of the French designer’s work and life.

The exhibition runs from 11 July – 25 October 2015 and features these creations and more

cards.title: Labour leadership hustings / Cooper and Burnham attack Kendall's support for free schools
cards.rawTitle: Cooper and Burnham attack Kendall's support for free schools

item.title: Labour leadership hustings: Cooper and Burnham attack Kendall's support for free schools
item.trailText: Yvette Cooper and Andy Burnham critisise Liz Kendall's support for the government's free schools during the latest hustings for candidates vieing for leadership of the Labour party
item.standFirst: Yvette Cooper and Andy Burnham criticises Liz Kendall's support for the government's free schools during the latest hustings for candidates vying for leadership of the Labour party. Speaking at the event in Stevenage on Saturday, Cooper and Burnham describe the free schools programme as 'a waste of money' and take issue with Kendall's previous comments that people who want to run new schools deserve 'credit not criticism'

cards.title: Charleston shooting / Rick Perry describes it as an 'accident'
cards.rawTitle: Rick Perry describes it as an 'accident'

item.title: Rick Perry describes Charleston church shooting as an 'accident'
item.trailText: Republican presidential candidate Rick Perry suggested on Friday that the fatal shooting at Emanuel AME church in Charleston, South Carolina, was an 'accident'
item.standFirst:
Republican presidential candidate Rick Perry suggests on Friday that the fatal shooting at Emanuel AME church in Charleston, South Carolina, was an 'accident'. The former Texas governor was asked about the shooting, in which nine black people were killed by a white male, during an interview with the conservative NewsmaxTV. A spokesman for Perry later clarified that he had meant to say 'incident'

• Watch the full interview here

cards.title: Video / London tour bus driver was 'filmed running red light'
cards.rawTitle: London tour bus driver was 'filmed running red light'

item.title: London tour bus driver throttles woman who 'filmed her running red light'
item.trailText: A London tour bus driver is filmed apparently throttling a passerby after witnesses say the victim filmed her running a red light in Waterloo
item.standFirst: A London tour bus driver is filmed apparently throttling a passerby after witnesses say the victim filmed her running a red light. The driver leaves her Golden Tours bus running in the middle of Stamford Street, Waterloo, during the incident. Other pedestrians come to the aid of the victim, who can be heard screaming before falling to the ground
